Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Civil Part — Mercer County

MER-L-002371-25 – Emergency Injunction (Mercer)

MER-L-002371-25 · Docket MER-L-002371-25

Case Type
Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Status
Active
Forum
Trial Court
Role
Plaintiff
civil equitable-relief declaratory-relief

Case Overview

Active Law Division civil action seeking emergent equitable and declaratory relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. The action challenges the warrantless seizure and continued retention of Plaintiff’s vehicle without statutory authority, judicial process, or due process, and seeks immediate return of property and related equitable relief.

MER-L-002371-25 – Emergency Injunction (Mercer)

Case Overview

Docket No.: MER-L-002371-25
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Civil Part – Mercer County
Plaintiff: Devon Tyler Barber (pro se)
Defendants: City of Trenton; Officer John Doe 1; Officer John Doe 2
Case Type: Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Primary Relief Sought: Immediate return of unlawfully impounded vehicle; declaratory and equitable relief

Nature of the Action

This is an emergent civil action seeking immediate injunctive and equitable relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. Plaintiff challenges the seizure and continued retention of his 2019 Volkswagen Passat (NJ Plate F35VLP), which was taken and held without statutory authority, court order, forfeiture process, or constitutionally adequate due process.

Core Facts

  • On December 7, 2025, Trenton police officers seized Plaintiff’s vehicle following a traffic stop and custodial arrest.
  • The arrest resulted in municipal-level charges, none of which authorize vehicle impoundment under Title 39 or any forfeiture statute.
  • The vehicle was operable, legally parked, not contraband, not evidence, and posed no public-safety hazard at the time of seizure.
  • No forfeiture complaint, warrant, inventory, or judicial order has ever been issued authorizing continued retention of the vehicle.
  • Defendants have refused to release the vehicle unless towing and storage fees are paid, despite the impoundment being unlawful ab initio.

These facts are set forth in sworn certifications and a verified complaint filed with the Court.
